projects.title: MTB Group Ride
projects.subtitle: Community-driven group ride planning for mountain bikers
projects.overview: MTB Group Ride is a full-stack web application designed to make it easier for mountain bikers to discover, organize, and join local group rides. While many existing tools focus on tracking rides or displaying trail data, MTB Group Ride centers on community — helping riders actually meet and ride together in real life.

problem.content: Group rides are often organized through fragmented tools like Facebook groups, group texts, and forums. This makes it difficult for riders — especially those new to an area — to discover rides or participate consistently. At the same time, popular MTB apps focus heavily on ride tracking and trail information, but not on connecting the people riding those trails.
problem.note: Trail data is widely available, but tools that help riders coordinate and build community around that data are lacking.

solution.intro: MTB Group Ride provides a simple, mobile-friendly platform that allows riders to:
points: Create and discover group rides in their area
View rides in relation to nearby trails using interactive maps
Receive email notifications when rides are updated
Browse rides through a clean, calendar-based interface
solution.note: The experience was intentionally designed to be fast, intuitive, and usable from a phone — including at the trailhead.

parts.title: Backend & Data
points: Supabase for authentication and data access

technicalApproach.note: Key technical challenges included designing flexible data models for rides and locations, handling partial trail data coverage, and building the system in a way that could evolve as new regions and integrations are added.

tradeoffs: Focused initial trail mapping on Georgia to validate real-world usage before expanding coverage
Built web-first rather than native to reduce friction and iterate quickly
Designed the platform to function even without guaranteed third-party trail APIs

points: Live users and recurring ride creation
Organic adoption by local MTB groups
Direct user feedback actively shaping feature direction
impact.note: While still early, the platform has validated the core use case of community-focused ride coordination.

demonstrates: Product thinking grounded in real user needs
Experience shipping, maintaining, and iterating on a live application
Comfort working with real-world constraints and incomplete data

projects.title: YT Industries
projects.subtitle: Frontend & full-stack development for a global mountain bike e-commerce platform
projects.overview:
I spent five years at YT Industries working across multiple generations of their e-commerce platform. My role spanned frontend and full-stack development, supporting both a legacy commerce site and a later transition to a headless frontend architecture. 

The platform served a global customer base and supported high-traffic, revenue-critical user flows across multiple regions.
role: Built and maintained production frontend features for the e-commerce site
Delivered UI work that balanced performance, usability, and conversion goals
Collaborated closely with product managers, designers, marketers, and analytics teams
Supported internationalization and localization across multiple markets
Worked within and improved long-lived codebases under real business deadlines

parts.title: Backend
points: Backend feature development and data modeling within an e-commerce system

parts.title: Architecture & Platform
points: API-driven communication between frontend and commerce backend

technicalApproach.note: The platform evolved significantly over my tenure, requiring adaptability to new technologies and architectures while maintaining a focus on delivering reliable, high-quality user experiences.

projects.takeaways: Working on a global e-commerce platform taught me how production systems evolve over time — including how to balance UX, performance, maintainability, and business requirements. This experience strongly influenced how I approach architecture, tradeoffs, and decision-making when building and owning products independently.
projects.why: My time at YT Industries grounded my development approach in real-world constraints: legacy systems, incremental modernization, cross-team collaboration, and long-term maintainability. It gave me a strong foundation for working as a frontend-leaning full-stack developer on modern, product-driven teams.
